reviewText:
IntroductionThe first Evoland was fun and unique, but at the same time also very short, linear and, dare I say, even a bit boring. So, has the game evolved into something better with Evoland 2 or is it just more of the same with more of that gimmicky gameplay? Read all about it right here!

GameplayTo be short and to be honest it really is more of the same. But it’s done way better, for the most part. While the first one was to-the-point and focused (maybe a bit too focused) this sequel takes the time to expand on pretty much everything. But, like everything, this has some positive and negative effects.

First of all, the script has been upgraded. This in turn makes the story much, much longer and more fleshed out and it might possibly make you feel for (one or more of) the characters that accompany you on your journey. There are some funny moments and a whole lot of references to popular movies, TV shows and other games. It all still is rather linear, though, so I guess that hasn’t changed, and it also feels too ‘old school’ at times, but just wrapped in a more modern package.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=531355732
The engine has also been upgraded to allow more types of gameplay to be shown. While there are still gameplay sections in it that you have also already played during the first game there are now many more. I can’t list them all I’m afraid, partly due to the character limit and my memory, but a few of the new gameplay types included are puzzles (clearly inspired by Professor Layton), music segments (clearly inspired by Guitar Hero), shoot ‘em ups (‘bullet hell’-like games) and stealth (clearly inspired by Metal Gear Solid).
I personally think it’s incredibly impressive to have an engine that can handle and show all these different types of gameplay and graphics without breaking a sweat. And I haven’t encountered any loading screens either, now that I think of it (except for the initial loading screen, but that speaks for itself I think).

The problem with having many types of different gameplay is that, even though there are a lot of fun ones, there will always be genres that people just dislike and maybe even hate. Now that most of these gameplay types have been expanded upon it’s possible that parts of it might start to drag or bore sooner than the developer had hoped for. I personally hated the shoot ‘em up part; it felt that it took too long and it was also quite challenging. But, then again, you can’t please everyone. But they certainly tried, that’s for sure.

However, none of the added gameplay types really add anything to the game, but like the first game it’s a fun ride if you’ve been playing games all your life or if you are just interested in game history. You will see a lot of different types of gameplay come by during your playthrough.
But I can’t help but wonder if the game would’ve been even better if they had focused on just a couple of gameplay mechanics (the ones you would normally see in other RPGs plus a few unique ones) instead of adding tens of different, sometimes even useless, genres and mechanics. Probably not, though.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=531355768
And even though it’s just a small part of the game the puzzles are, everything considered, well done, except for one or two. Unfortunately one of them even ‘broke’ the game for me as it became unsolvable. I am talking about the mammoth puzzle, which I was unable to solve on my first try. It’s actually really easy, but I did something (read: chose poorly) and wasn’t able to solve the puzzle because of it. With no way to reset the puzzle or fix it I had to load up my previous save game, which was fortunately just one or two minutes earlier. A bit sloppy, but I can forgive them.

Audio & VisualsThe music is exactly what you would expect in a game like this. It has a modern, symphonic soundtrack, similar to a lot of other soundtracks from years and games gone by. Rest assured: it’s not plagiarism. And somehow it also still has that retro feel.
The sound effects are also great, with a lot of beeps and ‘plings’ that we all should be familiar with I think. There is no voice acting, by the way.

Like the many genres included the game also has many (although not as many) different graphics. These range from 32-bit 2D and 2.5D to 3D, and each has its own style. It all runs at a solid 60FPS, too, and the colors just pop off the screen; they’re very vibrant and sharp, which I always love.
But in comparison it looks mostly the same as the first Evoland, with naturally some improvements added here and there.
All in all Evoland II manages to keep the graphics quality very consistent for the entire duration of the game. Another impressive feat for such a lengthy game!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=531355823
Length/Replay ValueWhere the first Evoland took roughly 3-4 hours to complete the length of the sequel has been increased to at least 19 hours, and most of it feels like proper content and not just filler content.
You can put in even more hours than that if you want to collect absolutely everything so all things considered it’s definitely worth the asking price. It might not be interesting for the entire duration, but almost every game suffers from that problem in my opinion.
It’s also not a game that you will replay often; once you’re done with it it’s likely you won’t play it again until at least several months/years later, and most of you (including me) probably won’t ever play it ever again. Still, absolutely worth the asking price if you ask me.

ConclusionWow, Evoland II sure managed to impress me. I expected more of the same to be honest, which is definitely true, but the sequel pretty much improves on every aspect of the first game. It doesn’t make the game perfect – there are still a few flaws here and there – but I absolutely like the direction it’s heading into. There are also still a few too many gimmicks gameplay wise, but if they promise to take care of this in Evoland 3 (either by removing them or fleshing them out) then I’m sure it will be nothing short of amazing. An amazing love letter to videogames (as well as other media)! Bravo!

I didn't play the first Evoland game, but when I had the opportunity to meet up with Shiro Games on gamescom 2015, the first thing they told me was that they took the time, over a year, to analyse what could have been better on Evoland and make sure that their next game would show an improvement. I just finished the game, and I can clearly tell you that they did, all in all, a good job with this new Action-RPG title.

One of the most critical points for Evoland was that it was far too short and it somehow let people empty-handed. My first playthrough, played very casually but still trying to unlock additional content, just clocked at 23 hours, in-game time. Even if some stages or scenes can feel a bit lengthy, there's always something to do in this game: you can progress through the story, you can explore the world and try and find hidden chests or new items or you can spend hours trying to defeat tough opponents in their card game.

You are never bored when you explore the world of Evoland: there is always a hidden reference for you to catch. You will be meeting up with characters from your favorite video games (Elizabeth from Bioshock Infinite, Sakura from Street Fighter, Lara Croft...), you will notice items coming from different universes (mention to the Valley of Wind shop with Captain America's shield on a wall just next to a Buster Sword and Link's Hylian shield). To be honest, at first, I even thought it was too much, all the time, and I had the feeling that this game might even get sued for being just a huge pile of copyrights infringements. But when you decide to play the game for what it is, a sort of homage to past glories like Chrono Trigger or Secret of Mana, you are just having a blast.

Nicolas Decasse, one of the developers, introduced himself as a huge fan of Chrono Trigger, and the scenario of the game clearly shows it: the plot of the game will have you travel through time, using magic stones erected by a now disappeared civilization, while making sure you learn that this power shouldn't be messed around with and that your actions can have dire consequences. As every hero, Kuro, your avatar, will meet new friends on the way, and create special bounds with him. They will help him explore his environment, and he will be able to call on their power to progress through the game, by removing obstacles or creating paths for him. Once their power is fully unlocked, you will be able to use special summons for each of your three partners, like you would be able to in Final Fantasy 6 or 7.

Time travel is represented in a way that a lot of retrogamers are going to enjoy: depending on the era you're in, the more old school the graphics. 8 bits for the past, 16 bits for the present and isometric 3D for the future, you won't be able to forget in which era you're wandering. To explore certain areas, you will have to switch very regularly from one era to another, as some of the puzzles will involve removing obstacles or getting specific items in a different era to progress in the timeframe of your mission. This feature is very nice, but to be honest, from times to times, it just hacks the story telling: backtracking to one of those special stones to change something in another era before going back to the original era you come from and go back where you were is just a pain, at least in the first hours when you have no way of transportation.

However, Evoland 2 always finds a way to renew your interest, by breaking the habit and having the player to explore regularly new video game genres: you will have for instance to defeat a boss in a versus fighting mode, you will try to save an entire civilisation playing a tactical RPG mode, you will have to escape a mountain fighting your way through a bullet hell... You never know what to expect in your first playthrough, and I certainly didn't expect to have to play a mix of Dance Dance Revolution and Guitar Hero in an Action-RPG! My only problem with that is that it reinforces the general impression that the game is just a pot pourri of references and that it lacks a bit of personality: you play a game that talks and shows more of other games than itself.

One of the main criticisms I'll have for this game is that some of the puzzles it offers are just extremely hard to solve, and not because you need a master's degree to solve them.  No, I'm just referring to some tricky hitboxes or silly point of views that actually make you think you're stuck when you just have to move a couple of millimetres to see where you need to go or finally manage to destroy something that was blocking your way. I spent one hour looking for an exit in a forest, knowing where the only exit was, and not managing to open it because of the hitbox of the bush I was supposed to destroy was very tiny and made me think that I couldn't go there just yet. But all in all, the puzzles are kind of tricky in the game and you will have to think for a couple of minutes to solve most of them (just have a look at the discussion boards on Steam and check the numbers of Blocked in XXX" threads).

All in all

reviewText:
Evoland 2Developer: Shiro Games
Publisher: Shiro Games

Note: A key for this game was provided by the developer for the purpose of writing an unbiased informative review. No other compensation was given.

Introduction
==========
The original Evoland was somewhat of a surprise gem, utilizing some of the best features and gameplay from RPGs of the past. Expertly blended together, Evoland was a fun unique experience. Evoland 2 does nothing less than the same, crafting a wonderful experience using gameplay elements and mechanics from not only RPGs, but many other genres and series as well. You will see a lot of influences from many games, and many direct references scattered throughout. Even some pop culture references!

Gameplay
==========
Evoland 2 is an action RPG first and foremost, but at times it changes up its style for periods of time. In one segment of the game, you are able to explore the field much like in the classic Secret of Mana style, attacking enemies that wander around the field. In the next segment, you will be platforming through a dark dungeon very reminicent of the old Super Mario titles. This change of style helps keep Evoland 2 fresh, and it lends this feeling of excitement to the game where you press on to see what type of changes come next!

As the style changes, so do the graphics. You will start your adventure with what looks like the classic Game Boy look, black/white/grey pixels makign up your character and the world. This quickly evolves into a better 2D top-down look, in full color and a bit more detailed. Further progression sees full 3D being implemented, increasing the depth and overall look of the game. The original Evoland was all about going through the history of video games, and Evoland 2 still retains some of that feature.

The original Evoland had a traditional turn-based RPG battle system, with a few changes here or there. In Evoland 2, combat is much like Secret of Mana or The Legend of Zelda: enemies are out in the open--you can walk up to them and whack them with your sword while avoiding their attacks. Much like Secret of Mana, you also get a few companions as you progress. But unlike Evoland, they do not join you in battle directly and take their own turns. Instead, you can charge up a Focus Attack that will cause your partner companion to unleash a special attack. After using this, a short cooldown occurs before it can be used again. These Focus Attacks are not only ways to battle enemies, but they are also used to interact with the environment. Menos' attack, for example, can be used to damage groups of enemies or destroy blocks, boulders, or other such obstacles on the field. These abilities can be upgraded as you progress and collect Maana.

Graphics
==========
The overall look and feel of the game changes as you progress the story. At first, it's very simple: pixelated and colorless. But as you progress, it goes full 3D and filled with color and detail. No matter which stage of the game you are in, even the very beginning, the game looks amazing. It just keeps getting better as you go!

Character sprites at the beginning look nice enough, and when they hit 3D mode you really notice the little details. Attacks looks better, environments look better, everything just looks so much better as you go! It's really amazing how well the art direction of this game was handled.

Sound and Music
==========
One of my favorite parts of Evoland 2 is the soundtrack, especially in the Haunted Forest. The soundtrack perfectly matches each situation you encounter, the town you are visiting, or the dungeon you are exploring. Cheery, playful tunes for the towns set the mood for them well, and the dark, foreboding songs of each dungeon really make you feel like you are really there in the damp darkness. There is some very light voice acting, at least thus far, in the form of shouts, grunts, and other similar sounds. Swinging your sword is satisfying, as is the sound when hitting an enemy.

Performance
==========
Evoland 2 runs flawlessly on my rig, which I like to call a low mid-tier build. 60 FPS at all times, with no lag or slowdown. No frame drops whatsoever were observed. It plays perfectly with my Logitech F310 controller, with no prior setup. The default controls were spot on and easy to acclimate to. That being said, a controller is highly recommended.

Final Thoughts
==========
If you enjoyed the first Evoland, you will undoubtedly enjoy Evolnad 2 as well. It's a great nostalgic throwback to the games it draws some of its features and mechanics from, and you will surely recognize where a lot of them come from. Tons of easter eggs and references are scattered throughout too, making it an even more nostalgic experience. A must buy for fans of the original Evoland!

Evoland 2 Review - 30.08.2015
I have a passionate love-hate relationship with this game.
I've been thinking about recommending it forever and here's why I even struggled in the first place: The game's core is great. Some of the different gamemodes are just a blast, I especially digged the tactical rpg part, but some of them (I'm looking at you, Bejeweled) are just -horrible-. I played the entire game on hard, except for this one Bejeweled part that is literally impossible when your enemy just deals 90% of your life in a single swipe.

Apart from that, here's the deal. The game is amazing, yet it manages to annoy you every so often. Some parts are super tedious, occasionally, I just wanted to see if I could re-enter a certain gamemode or stage and then I had to play the entire level again because there's no option to turn back. Same thing with some sort of stealth segment, turns out, if you talk with a certain guard and hit yes (I wanted to see what he replied...) you go straight back into jail. However, even though there a lot of bugs and glitches, it was still super enjoyable. Because the plot is well done, the music is amazing, the gameplay feels (for the most part. ♥♥♥♥ Bejeweled.) good and the controls are tight and responsive. It really sets you back with a bazillion references to older games. I don't even want to spoil a single one, so you can experience it for yourself. So, after this short wall of text, let's review.

+ Amazing Gameplay for the most part.
+ Stunning visuals. (Mostly the Pixel Art though)
+ Amazing humour. Yes, it is THAT good.
+ Stays true to what it does. (Basically, the different gamemodes feel like they should, is what I'm trying to say.)
+ Time Travel Mechanics really add to the plot.
+ Now that I mentioned it, the plot is pretty sweet too, with a satisfying ending. (For me, that is. I did notice some people complain about it being too open ended, which is not really the case.)

- Tedious Mechanics, occasionally.
- Bejeweled
- Bugs/Glitches appear way too often, expect to restart the game or quit to title occasionally. (For example, do not open the treasure radar in the tactical rpg section. ♥♥♥♥ goes down.)
- Bejeweled
- Unintentional re-playing of various long and annoying sections, though I guess that was my fault.
- Bejeweled

TL;DR:
Good game, you should give it a shot, ♥♥♥♥ Bejeweled.

When I played the first Evoland game I enjoyed it and thought it was a nice little parody but really nothing more. That is why I was pretty hesitant at first at buying the second game. Then I saw some videos of the game and decided it was worth a shot, and boy am I happy about that decision.

From 2D top-down perspective to 3D navigation, from turn-based battle mechanics to real-time fighting and puzzle solving, from card games to shoot 'em up, this game excels in variety.

In addition, unlike the first game, Evoland 2 has a solid plot which in my opinion was very nice and enjoyable (no spoilers here).

For completionist this game is pretty much ideal as it offers many not-so-easy-to-find collectibles (non of which are missable, hurray!)

And finally, one does not simply write a review of this game without mentioning THE SOUNDTRACK. The music is so, so good! I find myself sitting and listening to the soundtrack of this game over and over again (including now as I'm writing this review).

So, what are you waiting for? JUST BUY THIS GAME AS SOON AS POSSIBLE! You won't regret it!

reviewText:
Evoland 2 is a much needed improvement to the mediocure original release. It takes you along a fantastic journey and had me hooked from the very beginning and I enjoyed every moment of it!

Positives
Variety: The key word for evoland 2 is probably variety. The game has decided to combine elements of tonnes of different other genres into their game. These includes modes like shoot em up, Rhythm, Professor layton style puzzles, platforming, turn based strategy and so many more! Each of these modes aren't half done and just put together really quickly either. There all fully fleshed out with a lot of depth to them and could perhaps make complete games in their own right.

References: It features tonnes of references to movies, games and TV shows as well as others. Some are rather obscure and others are very stand out but all of them add a lot to the overall experience. These include things like doctor who, mario, zelda, star trek and probably loads more that I didn't even notice! I believe they even made a reference to themselves at one point by making fun of the random encounters in the first game.

Story: One of my biggest flaws about the original evoland was the boring story that it had. But this isn't the same with the sequel. The game is a wonderful intriguing story that holds itself well throughout the entire game. It features twists and turns. Each character is unique its own way and there are loads for you to talk to you. The dialog each character gives you is fantastic and it really gives them a personality. The story is set among time periods as you travel backwards and fowards through time.

Graphics: Each time period has it's own unique graphics style. They represent different periods in the eras of RPG's. The game styilizes these periods excellently and manages to put so much detail into them. I'm particularly fond of the games present era which I believe to be styilized the best of them all and I was always amazed by the beauty of it whenever exploring the world.

Soundtrack: A wonderfully crafted soundtrack full of so many different songs. Each area you explore seemingly has a different track attached to it. The game even has varients of many of the tracks for different eras of gaming. The tracks perfectly fit the areas you are exploring and greatly and to the experience.

Length: The main story took me a full 21 hours to complete. A great length and such a difference to the original that only took me 3 hours to complete. There is still tonnes more for me to do in the game as I am currently at 70% progress.

Bosses: Some of the best bosses I have seen in a game before. Each are unique and completely different to anything i've seen before. They are all frustrating difficult to complete though. The final boss took me over an hour to complete.

Neutral
Changes: If you absolutely loved the original then you definitely won't find the same experience here. It doesn't teach you about the eras of RPG's very much at all in this game. It definitely isn't it's main focus. But instead you manage to get a well fleshed out experience. I'm neutral on this because I believe the original concept of the evolution of RPG's was too limiting for them to fill a full game with it.

Negatives
Bugs: I did manage to unfortunately experience a few game breaking bugs throughout. These included getting stuck in the world and a boss fight that froze and wouldn't finish. They hit me a few times meaning I had to restart the game to be able to continue. They were frustrating. But luckily you shouldn't have to deal with these problems. I posted onto the steam forums these bugs and the devs managed to fix them within only a few hours!

Leveling up: The game features a leveling system when you pick up experience points. When you level up you gain either life, defence or attack statistics. The problem I have with this is that you don't actually get to choose what's upgraded. The game chooses it for you leaving it feel rather pointless. The other problem I have is that the entire world seems to level up and get stronger with you meaning you don't feel the progression. This may be more of a general problem I have with all RPG's though.

Controls: I would strongly recommend a controller for this game. Keyboard has horrible key bindings that can't be changed.

Overall
I mean overall evoland 2 is a fantastic well fleshed out RPG with tonnes of variety and a great story. My negatives aren't too big of an issue and won't cause you to have too bad of an experience. So I think this game should appeal to everyone and should definitely be played by everyone! The price may seem a bit steep but for the amount of content you get it is well worth it!

Improving vastly over the previous instalment, Evoland 2 is a must-play for fans of action RPGs. The game’s world is rich with backstory, the characters are entertaining and the original content is far more enjoyable than I ever imagined. The game is however buggy, and you will need to restart the game a few time. Small patchable flaws aside, this game is a thoroughly enjoyable tale of time travel and destiny. The use of different graphical styles is something truly memorable and engaging, and this time it’s been used as an effective storytelling tool as opposed to a gimmick.

First and foremost, Evoland 2 does almost everything better than the series’ overly disappointing introduction. The use of different graphical designs are now integral to the narrative, representing what era your group of time traveling heroes are currently in. The story has been drastically improved, offering a much deeper lore, with pivotal moments in its history. The characters are engaging, and their dialogue is fun and sometimes even heart-breaking. Simply put, if Evoland was a shoddy attempt at a good idea, its sequel is the redemption.

While the first game felt like it was pandering to its audience, throwing any random gaming reference at them, Evoland 2 pulls back the needless illusions and allows the gameplay to do more of the talking this time around. This pleasant change allowed the developers more creative freedom, and it shows in this instalment.

The story is about a young man who’s discovered in the woods by a girl named Fina. The two of them venture out, seeking his true identity when they end up getting involved in a confrontation between an empire and a group of enslaved demons. They’re suddenly whisked many years into the past, and begin their journey towards discovering your identity, stopping a destructive war and returning everyone home.

While Evoland barely had a story to speak of, Evoland 2 addresses the problem with a vengeance. The plot thickens as you progress through a story clearly inspired by Chrono Trigger, as new twists seem to pop up after every new quest. Themes such as free will, destiny and prejudice are used as a driving force, and it makes the game all the more enjoyable. You constantly want to get to the next quest, and I was delighted when I was rewarded with new exploratory options. There’s something about old RPGs, where something as small as getting a paddle boat is somehow amazingly liberating; something that many modern games don’t seem to get right.

Like the classics mini-games of the past, Evoland 2 nails mixing up the gameplay. In one section, you’ll jump into an Active-Time Battle system ala the Chrono series. These ideas could’ve been phoned in, but the developers at Shiro Games included a nice simple selection of moves and even environmental conditions for this mode. You’ll have to time your attacks, as the lights cut in and out or when you’re avoiding electrified floors that’ll nullify your attacks. These modes are not just RPG inspired either- they also have a space shooter segment, where Galaga fans will feel right at home blasting their way through enemies. There’s even several bosses, all with their own patterns to figure out. There’s a 2.5D fighter segment, side-scroller platforming, Bomberman inspired levels- and it does all of them right. There’s even a card game. Okay- that one does suck, but has there ever been a good card game in an RPG?

One thing I can’t ignore though, are the glitches. Oh man- this is truly heart-breaking. I had to restart this game more times than a thirty dollar android phone. Graphics would simply drop out. Mine carts would randomly appear on the tracks preventing me from progressing. Sound effects would suddenly loop in-game, even when I went back out to the menu. My goodness, what a horrible state this game is being released in. While it was annoying, backing out of the game is fast, and I could always get back to where I was quickly- but I’d be remiss if I didn’t mention these grievous oversights. I will say, the game feels ambitious, so a few glitches can be expected, but these were pretty hard to swallow.

And I think that might be my biggest complaint about the game; all the references. While I laud the developers for running with a ‘parody all the games’ mind-set, they’ve now tuned the machine so well, it’s actually quite good without a gimmick. When you stumble upon a reference, it only pulls you out to remind you that you’re playing what’s ‘pretending’ to be a game. The reference may be light enough, like seeing Sir Dan from MediEvil in a dungeon’s corner- it’s when that reference becomes too obvious or obnoxious that it really hurts the overall mood of the game; like finding a mystery box straight out of the Mushroom Kingdom. In a game packed full of allusions, some are going to work, and some are going to make you shake your head in disappointment. Thankfully, the game has more winners than losers, but those stinkers reared their head in all the wrong places, including a poorly timed Professor Layton reference right at the beginning of the game.

There were times in the game when I really wondered whether this was going to be a yes or a no, but the good parts of Evoland 2 ultimately outshone the bad. Recommended for any fan of 2D Zeldas and anyone who enjoyed the first game. If you're in neither of those categories and the concept alone doesn't make you desparate to play it, wait for a sale.

Detailed review:

Gameplay:
It's impossible to delve into too much detail here without spoling what games Evoland 2 mimics, and that surprise is the heart of the game. Like the first game, E2 takes place primarily in three eras representing approximately the NES, SNES, and mid-early 3D eras of gaming. Also like the first game, it apes Final Fantasy (and now Chrono Trigger) in its story and most frequently takes its gameplay Zelda titles like A Link to the Past and Link's Awakening. E2 remains highly competent in this department, but problems start to arise when the gameplay tries to explore other genres. The game steadfastly refuses to use any buttons beyond the arrow keys, shift, space, and tab even when that means compromising essential functions of the games it's trying to imitate. The benefit to this approach is that the game never needs a second tutorial, but the price is that some segments feel incredibly simplistic and suffer as a result. Other segments were simply outside the expertise of the development team and have serious design flaws. Still others are poorly explained.

Thankfully, none of the bad segments stick around for long. You'll remember the frustrations for how egregious some of them are, but in terms of time there's far more to like than dislike. The game knows it's better at certain genres and largely sticks to them.

Sound:
Inconsistent. There are a few really good tracks, a lot of mediocre ones, and a theme that was so awful I muted the entire game for the brief time it was playing. The sound gets the job done in-game, but I can't possibly recommend buying the OST for full price.

There's a lot of audio-skipping/freezing in the game as a result of a nasty bug that occurs seemingly randomly during transitions and loading of certain special attacks. It happened around two dozen times in my game and sometimes lasted around 5 seconds.

Graphics/Performance:
The 2D sprite worlds are quite well done and the 3D graphics do what they need to. I didn't run into any performance issues except on my laptop (Intel HD 4500), which struggled with the 3D world. Loads are all very quick in spite of the above audio issues.

Story:
E2's story follows E1's theme of being a blatant Final Fantasy parody, but this time around the writing is better, more serious, and more extensive. It's not about to win the Nobel Prize in Literature, but there are some geniunely funny moments and the plot as a whole does a great job of staying entertaining. It even manges to be a time travel story without too many blatant plot holes, which is a rare accomplishment.

Value/Replayability:
Lasts around 16 hours if you're just trying to get through it. Completionists can probably add another 5-6 on top of that for optional puzzles and quests. There's no NG+, but you can load your pre-final boss save and continue playing with access to (almost) everything.

reviewText:
Welcome to self referntial humor the video game!  If someone else has made a game, we'll reference it!

Sigh...I enjoyed the first Evoland as a fun, quirky trip through RPG history without to much substance.  Evoland 2 tries to have a more grandiose story and more varied gameplay, but...it's so frustrating, clunky, and...unfun.  Where do I start...the music is repetitive and painful.  Turn it down early and often.  The graphics are charming and we go through a number of different palattes but overall it feels very thrown together.  The story and script try very hard to be funny, but they're...just not.  Not really.  And the game modes...Evoland 2 tried to throw as many game modes into a blender as possible to appeal to everyone.  If you've seen the trailer, it probably looks cool, right?  The rpg modes, the fighting game modes, the shooter modes...except that no one thought to ask if these SHOULD be thrown together.  These modes are all very clunky and clumsily executed, go on for way too long, and are frankly, tiresome and frustrating.

The game, on the whole, is glitchy and buggy in many small ways, from controls locking up after passing doors, to the poor hit boxes, to the overall inexperience and clumsiness we feel in some of the newer modes, fighting game especially.  In some cases, there is a distinct lack of clever level design, such as the frustrating megaman style jumping sections on disappearing and reappearing blocks when we shift to side view.

This game feels like it was trying to copy Chrono Trigger in story and be a grand ride through game genres in execution, but it fails to do either.  The story falls flat for me and the game modes, while varied, are poorly executed at best, especially the 3d segments.

Give this game a pass.

This is a fantastic game.

The first Evoland mashed together a bunch of different art and play styles in a sort of 4th wall breaking meta-game. It was entertaining, but it was more of an amusement park filled with a bunch of different rides than a coherent gaming experience.

Evoland 2 is first and foremost a really solid RPG, which uses the changing art and play styles to put together a compelling story. The writing is superb, and the characters manage to be both parodies of classic RPG tropes and well developed and engaging at the same time.

reviewText:
Normally when it comes to games, the rule of thumb is - if you're not sure, wait until it's on sale and try it out. With Evoland 2 - just buy it, I can guarantee you'll love it.

When I first began playing Evoland 2, I won't deny it, I was initially disappointed. It isn't exactly like the first game, which is pretty much what I expected. I would have been disappointed if it had been a carbon-copy of the last game because there wasn't much you could roll with, but that was what I EXPECTED. You get thrown into the brand-new storyline, and it wasn't anything like the previous game at first. When you first play, if your initial expectation is Evoland 1 but with... I don't know, new graphics? You're going to be disappointed. Do not let this colour your experience of this game. Don't listen to those reviews - if you're after Evoland 1, go play Evoland 1 - this is Evoland 2, it is bigger, better, and far more enjoyable in my opinion (and I thought Evoland was great fyi)

Evoland 2 is a fantastic game, it's well rounded, the storyline is FANTASTIC, the game mechanics are done well, the soundtrack is killer, the characters are full of depth and they're original, they aren't your classic cliches. It literally has a bit of everything, just like the previous game - we've got sidescrollers, your traditional RPG, your new 3D RPG landscapes, there's stages of fight em' up, space invaders type scrolling, tower-defence style RPG, tekken-style fights, pretty much everything - heck, there's even a secret island that's full of Zelda-inspired cuccos!

Throughout the game there's a million and one easter eggs with throwbacks to your favourite classics, done tastefully. There's even a card game on the side that is done incredibly well - you'll have just as much fun finding the cards as you will playing the game - heck, it's something I think would work quite well in hard-copy.

I've spend 24.5 hours playing this game in the last two weeks alone. This says a lot - it was so much fun to explore, so much fun to play, so much fun to experience. Yes, there were some insanely hard stages that I found very difficult to pass, but it didn't detract from the game, this was merely a reflection of my skill (ie. I can't play Guitar Hero for sh*t).

As an added note, I highly recommend playing this game with a controller. It is playable with the keyboard, and I played through about half the game this way, however, you will probably find that playing with a controller makes it a lot easier to mash buttons when needed - but it is in no way a necessity - I would definitely recommend it for players who struggle through some stages (like oh my god the Biblus miniboss, my poor fingers).

Overall - I think the only criticism I have of the game so far is its replayability - when you're all done, you do get warped back to the very last save point before the final boss battle - which is okay because you have all the opportunities then to go back to each time period and find the remaining stars or cards you might have missed - but that's literally the only negative. I haven't enjoyed playing a game this much for quite a long time, and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
If you're looking for a tl:dr, I do recommend Evoland 2 despite it's faults. The gameplay is extremely varied, it has a unique mechanic regarding time travel that alters the graphics of the game, and there are also lots of references and jokes to other games in the genre making for some funny moments in a somewhat forgettable story. The story itself isn't bad, but it's nothing special. As long as you don't take it too seriously and ignore some of the paradoxes they've most likely created, you should find the story somewhat enjoyable.

Seriously, this game has the most varied gameplay I've ever seen. A good amount of the game is spent in the Zelda style top down view but there are sections where it goes completely 2D and turns into a platformer, a section where the game goes Final Fantasy style completely turn based, a Street Fighter style boss fight, a bullet hell segment, and even a village where you fight people in a modified version of Bejeweled! Every time I get to a new section, it feels like I'm playing a different game. This game does a lot to make sure it's not repetitive.

As much as there is to experience in this game, gameplay varied to this degree does have it's drawbacks. When you have so many different genres melding into one game, you're going to lose people at one point. Some sections you'll have a blast with and will be disappointed when they're over, while other sections will bore you and you'll be glad when that segment ends. Personally, I enjoyed the Bejeweled section but I was having a hard time getting through the Final Fantasy part since it felt like all I was doing was the same commands over and over again for every battle. Another unfortunate problem is that since the game has so many different mechanics regarding all the genre shifts, they aren't as fine tuned as their respective games. This was especially true during the Street Fighter segment. The controls were pretty clunky and when I pressed pause, it would show my moves list but not only did it disappear if you go to another tab but it also didn't list the move that uses your special meter.

Since Evoland 2 borrows a lot from other games, it only makes sense to have a little fun with it. I had a good laugh when one of the ladies in town said I should be wary of a boy wearing green clothing who goes into people's houses and smashes their pots. As for the main story, there's not much to say really. The game starts off with a main character with amnesia cliche but after meeting the girl who took care of you while you were out cold, you quickly start your adventures through time. The characters all have funny dialogue and do have character progression. It is a time travel story though so expect some paradoxes and the usual confusion that comes with quantum physics. With the amount of jokes it makes towards other games and even at itself, I don't believe the story is too serious. As long as you don't expect it to be the next Mass Effect or something with it's storytelling, you'll most likely enjoy what the story has to offer. Now the interesting thing about time travel in this game is that when you go back in time, the graphics do much of the same. It starts out looking like a Gameboy Advance game but when you go to the past, it looks like somewhere between NES and SNES. Going into the future makes the game go entirely 3D which could definitely pass as a late Gamecube/PS2 era game. With a mechanic like this, it makes exploring the world in two different time periods interesting in more ways than one.

Evoland 2 is a pretty decent game. I finished the game in 15 hours with a 67% completion rate so for you completionists out there, you can easily get another 5-10 hours out of this game. While the first Evoland was more of a brief parody of the adventure game genre, this game was more focused on standing out on it's own. They've taken a bunch of different gameplay styles and mashed them into one game. With all the references to other games, this game feels like a retrospective of not only what the adventure genre has branched off to, but also to what gaming has evolved into in general. We may have started out with simple games like Pac-Man and Super Mario but now we've got side scrolling beat em' ups like Final Fight, strategy RPG's like Fire Emblem, shoot em' up games like Star Fox, and so much more. I feel like that's where this game shines the most. It does have it's problems but in the end, it was nice to experience a taste of all the different genres the gaming industry has created.

reviewText:
Evoland 2 is a busy game, and it does so many different things that there is no way it can be good at all of them. While you travel through three main eras (think NES, SNES, and modern) there are many times where it switches to a totally different game genre for a one off joke or a boss fight.

You'll fight someone a la Street Fighter, play Bejeweled with some dudes, and shoot down enemies in both over head and side scrolling shoot 'em up style levels.

And here's the problem.

Some of these new modes control like crap, and are just awful in general. The over head shump was by far the worst part of the game. Not only is it a really bad shump, but it drags on for way too long. It also does this with a segment that wants to be an endless runner.

The game isn't all bad. There are some neat time travel mechanics that remind me a bit of Chrono Trigger, with your actions in one time having an effect on another.

There's also a card game you can play against various NPCs, but it is really bad. Your deck just consists of any cards you have, so if you unlock some crappy cards before some awesome ones (which is bound to be the case) have fun drawing those useless things since there is no way to edit the deck.

Your opponents in this card game also have life values that jump all over the place, while you are locked at 20hp. It feels like they are giving them more life to artificially make them more challenging fights instead of actually constructing better decks for the opponent.

Winning at the card game puts you at the mercy of the RNG. You can lose a fight time and time again, until it finally decides to give you a decent card order, and then you'll stomp it. It's sad, because there is a decent CCG hiding in here if they had just worked a bit more to make it something you can actually apply strategy to.

My biggest complaint, by far, is that there is no run button. Your character movies painfully slow, and I can't believe they didn't think to let you run. There are tons of unused buttons, so I don't know why they did this.

Evoland 2 is much longer than the first game, and I think it's worth the price, I just wish it had gotten a bit more polish.

Get. This. Game.

If you enjoyed the first Evoland game, you might be in for a slight dissapointment. But, before you go on and rant on how it's not exact. Read on. The reason for this 'dissapointment' is because Evoland 2 steps away from the linear straight-forward evolution of video game progression. Instead, Evoland 2 gives you all that the first Evoland had, improves, rewrites, and adds to it in a fantastic blend of multiple gameplay, graphics, and also a satisfying story that will keep you on your toes.

There is multiple genres of gameplay, including 2D platforming, Mortal Combat-esque battle, Tactical Turn-based, and also many, many others.

In Evoland 2, you start within the 'present', which is a sprite-based full-body graphical style. Evoland 2 main story-line involves Time-Travel. Going to the past will have graphics revert to more 'ancient' looking apperance, but still retain a modern fludity that will leave you breathless. As you go toward the future, it will transition to an 3D graphical apperance.

With Time-Travel comes the different gameplay methods as mentioned above. Though they will make their apperances as you progress through the story-line.

One of Evoland 2's main features is its companions. These memorable friends of your character each have their unique personality and abilities. Their abilities are neccessary for both story progression and completionist objectives. I personally found my first green-haired girl companion, whom I named 'Sinai' to be my character's best friend. I truly cared for her comments, personal story, and the way she acted.

There are a few segments I did find a bit irritating, sometimes overchallenging. In a few instances I had to tone down the difficulty from classic (Normal) to, uh, this game's version of 'easy'. If only just to get past and continue the story which I eagerly awaited to see it's next part.

The true Final Boss was not totally unexpected, and also seemed to come a little out of nowhere. It was one of the few kinks in the story that lacked some development. I wished they had fleshed out the Final Boss's story a bit more for me to actually care about the character instead of viewing her like somebody I just had to beat to finish the game.

Also, there are references everywhere... I spotted three clearly Dragon Ball Z references. And a whole lot more. But it's not a bad thing, it adds a certain flavor that fits well with Evoland 2, given its prequel.

My personal rating for this game is a solid 9/10. It's fantastic, keeps you interested, is fun to play, but does have a few annoyances and story-related holes. But don't let that deter you, Evoland 2 will keep you wanting to play, and if you love collecting things, you'll expand the 18-20 hour story to an addition 22-26, possibly more.

reviewText:
IntroductionThis game is a MASTERPIECE, the idea of the game itself (evolving gameplay) is a very brilliant and unique concept and it already deserves a plus point just because of that. The length is very acceptable, completed my first playthrough with 100% completion and 100% achievements within 20 hours++.
I won't talk about the game itself, like what you can find in the game, but I'll talk about my impressions about the game.

GameplayGameplay is the strongest point of the game imo. Evoland 2 offers you a variety of gameplay and the game really able to accommodate the concept to the game. All the changes in the gameplay is smoothly corporated into the storyline. Yes, there are a couple of genres that feels a little bit 'forced' but in the end it doesn't break the immersion. All in all, I feel like the storyline and the gameplay complements each other very well.

The thing is, you won't find any deep gameplay system. Some people might find it as the weakness, but I find it as the strength of Evoland 2. With the 'shallow' gameplay, you don't need long tutorial and most of the time, you basically will be able to play purely with your instinct only. And with the constant changing, you'll be able to explore what each gameplay able to offer just in time before you move on and change into another genre.

There are only 2 weaknesses that I found.
First, just like someone else mentioned, you're bound to find a genre that you don't like. Especially, naturally some genre will have more playtime compared to others.
Second, some genres are repeatable, but some are not which is a pity because I enjoyed some of those genres.

The difficulty itself is quite fair. I find it doesn't too hard but still challenging. I was able to get into level 30 with just a little bit of grinding. The puzzle in various parts are quite challenging too. It's like, it's not that obvious, once in awhile it still has that 'AHA!' moment for me.
The collectibles and achievements all are reasonable. They need some effort but not too annoying that forces you grinding like hell.

Also, I don't know whether it's just me, but I really enjoyed the Card Game. Actually it will be fun if we able to play it with other players.

Story & ScriptFirst, all those references to other games, I think it was very interesting and funny sometimes. It makes me keep entertained and keep on wondering whether this particular dialogue is just another script or a reference to something else.

Next, about the story of the game itself. This part gave the biggest impression for me, simply because I didn't expect it at all.
On my first hours of playing, I thought the game will just have a simple story. However it does able to keep me entertained and hooked until the end. It's a little bit linear, but I'm not a fan of open world game myself, so it does it just right for me.
The most interesting part is, right after I finished the game, I still thought the story is too simple and such. But after that, I pondered more about the story esp the ending of the game. Then I looked for discussion about the ending to confirm it and I was right. When you really pay attention to all the small details throughout the game, the story is actually pretty awesome. It does play with your mind and left me fascinated with it. There are still indeed lots of lingering questions in my mind. But overall it's very nice. In fact, it gave me the same feeling like when I finished watching a Nolan's movie.

OthersThe changing graphics is actually great and makes me feeling nostalgic too.
The BGM are pretty nice too.
I saw some people complained about hit boxes and such, however I didn't find any bug or annoying technical things like at all.

ConclusionEvoland 2 is a very recommended game, especially when you're familiar with various popular title from different genre since the older generation of console. During my playthrough, I kept on looking forward what's the next genre that the game will give me and also what reference of other game that I'll find.
The various genres, the jokes, the story, the changing graphics, all of them complements each other so well that they  make a complete and almost perfect package.
Evoland 2 is a very unique title and I can see myself replaying it again and again in the future :)

A chest that says: “this chest could be opened if the developers had time to code it”. A statue whose inscription says: “lorem ipsum dolor sit amet”. The most prominent issue I have with Evoland 2 is its inability to take itself seriously. It lingers in a weird limbo of humor and seriousness without fully committing to either. It’s littered with dank memes and clichéd, self-referential jokes which downplay the game's attempts at evoking emotions.

Dungeons, upgrades, levels, collectibles, dialogue options and NPCs are all ingredients to a decent RPG adventure but they’re not enough for an excellent one. The progress in Evoland 2 isn’t easily perceptible because the story is a convoluted mess. It sort of keeps moving and throwing twists, most of which overstay their welcome.

I also begun to hope that the NPCs would alter their lines the second time I spoke to them because I found myself repeatedly doing that by accident. The occasional meaningless yes/no choice adds nothing to the script, and there were some cases of continuation errors where my characters were talking about an obstacle they hadn’t yet seen in the game. Then there was the quite literal manic pixie dream girl calling me and my party member a bunch of pessimists, continuing to spout a mass of motivational quotes, which made me skip dialogue until my wrist hurt.

Music isn’t bad, it’s mediocre. The Haunted Forest area has an uptempo rock tune with a church organ giving it a Castlevania vibe and making it sound like a comedic boss battle. Compared to the music in Zelda, for example, Evoland 2 sounds like a Disneyland ride. Zelda’s Lost Woods tune is more ambiguous in its harmonization. It creates a contemplative ambiance, despite being upbeat.

The 3D environment simply fails to appeal. The saturated colors and the low-poly props look like they don’t belong on PC. The isometric world doesn’t encourage exploration because you can’t view a single vista in perspective.

Minigames in Evoland 2 are fine, but their framing isn’t. There’s a library with eight small puzzles. In Professor Layton the puzzles pace the gameplay through interesting locales. You’re compelled to investigate and just happen to come by tiny puzzles here and there. In Evoland, I ran from NPC to NPC and solved all eight puzzles in a row for study credits".

I don't like posting negative reviews, and despite my long play time (I left the game running over night a few times), I just don't find the game enjoyable.

Evoland, the original, was a much better game. You started out with a monochrome pixelated game that slowly evolved into something a whole lot better.  Evoland 2 decided to just throw together a whole bunch of random crap and call it a game.

Clearly the designers had no idea on how to enhance their first game, so they went for everything. So far I've encountered the low resolution monochrome game play, the 8 bit colour, the 16 bit colour and the modern 3D graphics game play. Those parts aren't too bad, however, instead of just using those features, Shiro Games threw in everything else, possibly including the kitchen sink (I haven't found that yet).

You now have forced on you, platform gaming, turn based RPG, endless running gaming, street fighter PvP and poorly implemented puzzle solving.  The only type of game I haven't come across yet is FPS, but I'm sure that's coming.  Adding to the unnecessary mix of genres is the tedium of being attacked over and over and over again in some of the levels. It is quite deliberate as a homage to these past genres.  It doesn't sit well in today's gaming style.

Add to that the convoluted story line, which has as much text to read through as Wikipedia seems to, and I find myself struggling to want to finish the game.

I won't comment on the music, I never listen to game music, I've never enjoyed any game music since the C64 days. If I want to listen to music, I'll play an MP3 or put on a CD.

Are there any positives ?  I like the mix in graphics, I just don't think it's done well this time around. In the first game the changing graphics showed progress, in this game the styles change constantly for what feels like no rhyme or reason.

Bottom line ? If you like tedious, repetitive and tedious and repetitive game play then look no further, however if you'd rather play a game that doesn't frustrate the crap out of you, go play something else.  Buy it on special or in a bundle if you must.

reviewText:
The first maybe hour or so of the game is quaint. Having played the first one, I thought it would be a natural progression from the first with some fixes to the complaints about the first. And it was, for a short amount of time.

Then you start getting hit by spikes you're nowhere near. Okay, fair enough, maybe I actually *was* barely touching the spike that instakilled me. At least the checkpoints are generous.

Then you get thrust into an unskippable fighting game scenario where the game doesn't tell you the controls, just what street fighter combos they decided to toss in, but the enemy you face can combo you for 75% of your health from the milisecond it gives you control of your character. Maybe I just don't know how to play fighting games and there's some weird trick to break out of combos they didn't mention were in the game.

Then you get forced into an auto scrolling rooftop run where the enemy will keep throwing energy attacks at you, each dealing more than half your health. Get hit more than once? Start over. Didn't break a box in enough time? Start over. Mash the jump button 100 times but still run off the edge? Start over.

Then you get put into a megaman style boss with an assload of health that rarely stops moving and does more than half your health per hit again. A mix of running in melee and throwing balls at you, at the default difficulty the balls are at a height such that you need to jump, but one more is just above you to hit you if you jump, and by the time you land the enemy is running or jumping at you, and you go from full to dead in a moment.

I won't say I'm great at videogames, but I don't consider myself the worst either. The first game took you through different types of RPGs from NES games to Playstation games. This one is a bit different in that it goes through different genres of videogames like shmups and fighting games, but rather than do one thing well, it does a bunch of things pretty poorly. It's one thing to have a difficult section or a ramp up, it's another to force the player to mash through dialogue before a fight just to have your character being attacked immediately when they die in 2 hits. It was fun at first, but you can save yourself some money by looking at screenshots or a handful of videos as it goes through each stage.

reviewText:
I enjoyed the original Evoland, but Evoland 2 has just not clicked as well for me.  I enjoyed the game to start, but at about 10 hours in, I think I'm ready to set down the controller and let this one go unfinished.

For myself, Evoland 2 just does not have the depth to hold up to the increased campaign time of ~20 hours.  The base RPG mechanics are fun, but not twenty-hours-fun.  This is a game at odds with itself -- the same things that made the first game great (and made the start of this one just as fun) are what were wearing thin for me as the game went on.  For a handful of hours, the simplistic mechanics are great -- but when you feel like you're on your 50th short fetch quest, that simplicity begins to grate at you.  And while I love some of the altered game modes, it was a Rayman boss-esque auto scrolling chase sequence that made me quit.  The side scrolling platform action sections?  Decent enough! The fighting game boss fight with the prophet?  Silly but fun.  The Shump section?  Dragged on to long, but not terrible.  But the boss runner -- no thank you.

I really hate giving a game with this much heart a thumbs down, but it's hard to recommend a game that, 5 months later, I just have no desire to finish.  Rather than take what Evoland did and do it better, I feel Evoland 2 just does more things -- but doesn't really do any of them very well.

Don't come into this for the story. I know I probably shouldn't have to say that after the first title, but it's equally true here. If the way Mass Effect 3 ended ♥♥♥♥♥♥ you off, you'll need to brace yourself with this one. A nonsensical ending to the story, which doesn't even wrap things up in every area. Unfortunantly I can't think of how I would elaborate on that without it being a spoiler, so I'll just leave it there. Just know that there are loose threads. The card game is inferior to the original, and still commits the deadly CCG sin of not allowing players to make their own deck. You'll cringe as you win cards whose ONLY use it to discard for points knowing that you'll wind up drawing them later. Won a card with zero attack? Enjoy drawing that rather than something useful. Not only does the AI get to use decks using only good cards while you're forced to use the weakest ones, sometimes the game even starts with the AI having up to twice as much health. While there are of course strategies you can use to mitigate risks, it ultimately relies on luck far more than any decent CCG should.

The game does get a bit confusing towards the end. You're told to go find 5 pieces of something, and you're given a hit to where each peice is. The problem is....that you might assume like I did that they were all valid choices to decide which one to go for first. In actuality, certain pieces have to be obtained for others, you so might waste hours looking for pieces which can't be obtained yet as I did. I think it would've worked better if the game told you which pieces to get in order.

I reccomend it because it is still an impressive feat. It is hard enough getting one set of mechanics to work when designing and programming. These guys had to make several sets of mechanics work, and aside from the bad design of the card game, they really pull it off. An enjoyable adventure which will eat up about 20-25 hours of your time if you 100% it. Evoland 2 is a big step up from its predecessor. While Evoland 1 was more of a fun gimmick with little story, the sequel stays within the gimmick of progressing through the history of changes in JRPGs and builds it into a fully fleshed out game. The gameplay is done very well, even with pulling from all of the vast archetypes of games over the last 30 years, it manages to not get too bogged down in trying to implement too many features. Definitely worth a pickup for any JRPG fans.

I played and enjoyed Evoland, so I was expecting not much more from Evoland 2 than what the first game had to offer. The game is an action/adventure/RPG game along the lines of Zelda (except you gain levels and HP), but throughout the game are homages to a surprisinly wide variety of genres, such as Bomberman, Street Fighter, Bejeweled, vertical scrolling arcade shooters, Chrono Trigger styled turn-based RPGs, DDR/Beatmania, Metal Gear Solid, Fire Emblem, Mega Man, side-scrolling shooters, platformers like Mario Bros, and even cameos of Pong, Snake, Space Invaders, and Pac Man. I try a lot of games and end up deleting the vast majority of them after 15 minutes (if that).

I could not stop playing Evoland 2. Some reviews say that the non-rpg elements are too hard, but playing the regular difficulty level, I've found it challenging at some points but forgiving (I've found that the harder it is, the more save points there are). I'll also point out that my awesome 2D scroller skills have disapeared in the ~20 years since I've last used them.

The base game of Evoland 2 reminded me very much of Dragon Warrior (Dragon Quest), one of my favorite game as a child. I guess it's not that hard to emulate the graphics, but I was amazed at how the dialogues from the useless NPCs were in line with how it used to be. I absolutely LOVED the variety in gameplay. That mix of elements is something that I've been wishing for for a long time, without thinking I'd ever see it realize.

After completing the game I rushed here to buy it and encourage everyone that tries a lot of games to do the same thing: I've seen too many great indie developpers go broke through the years. I will at least do another playthrough to try and beat my completion percentage (currently 86%).

The game is good, but has some flaws.

To start with, the game is no longer purely focused on RPGs. Players will be forced to enter different genres. Not a huge deal for those who are used to them, but this can cause players no familiar with those genres to get stuck.

Don't come into this for the story. I know I probably shouldn't have to say that after the first title, but it's equally true here. If the way Mass Effect 3 ended ♥♥♥♥♥♥ you off, you'll need to brace yourself with this one. A nonsensical ending to the story, which doesn't even wrap things up in every area. Unfortunantly I can't think of how I would elaborate on that without it being a spoiler, so I'll just leave it there. Just know that there are loose threads. It feels like they were nearing completion, got impatient, and just winged it on the ending. The game wasn't amazing by any stretch of the imagination, but it was satisfiying until the patch work at the end.

It appears some items are missable. Even with the dragon radar I can see exactly where certain items are, yet have absolutely no way of accessing them. And yes, I am familiar with the way that game sometimes uses intangible walls to create paths, I still can't reach certain chests.

The card game is inferior to the original, and still commits the deadly CCG sin of not allowing players to make their own deck. You'll cringe as you win cards whose ONLY use it to discard for points knowing that you'll wind up drawing them later. Won a card with zero attack? Enjoy drawing that rather than something useful. Not only does the AI get to use decks using only good cards while you're forced to use the weakest ones, sometimes the game even starts with the AI having up to twice as much health. While there are of course strategies you can use to mitigate risks, it ultimately relies on luck far more than any decent CCG should.

The game does get a bit confusing towards the end. You're told to go find 5 pieces of something, and you're given a hit to where each peice is. The problem is....that you might assume like I did that they were all valid choices to decide which one to go for first. In actuality, certain pieces have to be obtained for others, you so might waste hours looking for pieces which can't be obtained yet as I did. I think it would've worked better if the game told you which pieces to get in order.

I reccomend it because it is still an impressive feat. It is hard enough getting one set of mechanics to work when designing and programming. These guys had to make several sets of mechanics work, and aside from the bad design of the card game, they really pull it off. An enjoyable adventure which will eat up about 20-25 hours of your time if you 100% it. Don't expect game of the year material, but if you've got a weekend to burn then it's a quite enjoyable experience.

Throughout the game you will see the game acknowledging classic games like: Final Fantasy, Tomb Raider, Zelda, Metroid, Metal Gear Solid, TMNT, and many more. The game keeps the story rolling with mercifully placed saved points, and your ability to level up on the fly will pretty much assure your success.  The various types of puzzles found within this game haven't been annoying or tiresome.  I've found them to be fun to solve, and make sense to solve in relation to what is going on in the story.  The game's dialogue is well written, easy to follow, and necessary to the game play.  The PCs/NPCs are very likeable, and don't chatter on(except for one).

The card mini game has been entertaining, and particularly because a match is quick to play, the winning is fun, and the acquired cards are well done.

The only complaint I have is that you can't sprint? Yet?

Evoland's creators have done a great job of capturing the essence and innovations of classic games and woven them into their own game, which is equally as fun.

I Really wanted to like the game and most of the time I did. However, what should have been optional minigames became mandatory segments of the game, such as the rhythum boss fight and the Wiking tournament.  Also, far too many of the enemy attacks were not based on any gleanable patterns, and were almost entirely based on chance.

In a game of skill, applying RNG is an incredibly stupid thing to do, a terrible design flaw...

For sections such as the Wiking Tournament.. allow people to skip it. Penalize them a bit, make it cost gold

First things first, As I write this, Steam says I have only played 16 minutes. Well Steam is wrong. I have completed the entire game story-wise. (http://imgur.com/kHCnj79). On to the review!

Intro
====
The original Evoland was surprisingly good. Its main focus was on the gameplay and the concept of 'evolving' the game with sound effects, music, graphics and gameplay but the storyline was very simple. Evoland 2 took its predecessor and improved on pretty much everything!

Improvements
===========
-Shifting through time (changing graphics) is used lots later in the game and the shift is done very well.
-There are so many different locations and most contain their own unique gameplay or genre.
There's the main gameplay of the Legend of Zelda, 2D platformers, Street Fighter, 1942, Fire
Emblem and so many others!
-Each gameplay genre also has its own boss and if you are good at it/enjoy it, they won't last
for too long so that you get bored
-The game has a very deep storyline and will give you more hours of playtime than the first.
-Leveling up is relevant now! Your stats from leveling up carry through *most of* the different gameplay types.
-The card game is better if you want to waste time playing it. You find people to battle scattered across the map in
different times and you unlock more cards from beating other people.

Conclusion
========
Evoland 2 is a great game that improves on everything from the first Evoland. There are many different gameplay genres, the time travel is improved greatly and if you play through it all the way, it will provide you with much more playtime than the first. It doesn't provide me with many - if any major negative comments at all. Fantastic game!
Evoland 2: A Slight Case of Space Time Continuum Disorder - Highly Recommended

Note: Be prepared though because if you are bad at a genre that shows up or just don't like it, you have to complete it so if you find it too difficult, the only thing to do is practice, practice, practice. (Or find a loophole)

Evoland 2 is a great take on the classic JRPG and ARPG, ranking up there with Chronotrigger, Final Fantasy, and Legend of Zelda.  It's solid all on it's own, but if you're a veteran of the genre -- or really any gaming, you'll find it all the more enjoyable, with lots of clever references to everything from Mario, to Guitar Hero, to strategy games, to match-three, to Bomberman, to Lord of the Rings, to Game of Thrones.  It's very funny, never taking itself too seriously -- for example, on purchasing another sword, the game notes that an axe would have been a nice change-up but that the art team didn't have the budget.

The music is excellent, the art is great (jokes about the budget notwithstanding), and the gameplay is a perfect mix of tight controls, well-executed puzzles, and every RPG fighting convention you can think of (and then some.)  The level design throughout is fantastic and I can't speak highly enough about the excellent puzzles in the last few chapters of the game.  The gimmick -- switching from one time period to another is represented by different graphical styles from early Gameboy, to 8-bit, to 16-bit, to full 3d -- never feels like a gimmick.  It's organic within the confines of the story and is the source of both interesting challenges and lots of humor.

Speaking of the story, it's intriguing and doesn't end the way you'd expect.  It has some pretty deep philosophical underpinnings, something a bit surprising to find in this type of game.  It's a good length and doesn't overstay its welcome.  There's plenty to collect along the way as well and some (small) recognition for completing the game at various levels of completeness.

If you like JRPGs or ARPgs, you should play this game.  It's highly recommended.  I can't wait to see what Shiro Games comes up with next.

The previous entry to this series, Evoland, was a fantastic homage to gaming in general. The sequel, Evoland 2, took everything thing that was great about the original, improved upon it, expanded on it, and generally took things to 11.\n\nI highly recommend this game --- especially if you liked the original. My only gripe, if you can call it that, is that the game has a bit of a slower start than the previous game. This, however, is understandable when you consider the difference in size and scope.

A great game with a few flaws.  There are a wide variety of genres in this game, so sometimes you can get a bit stuck when one comes up that you are not good with.  For me, it was the roof-top runner section, which I had to attempt a lot before finally passing.  The good thing is that there are a lot of checkpoints, so you only have to repeat a small section of material for each attempt.

Another minor issue is that the plot can get a little bit messed up if you do certain sections out of the expected order.  In one part of the game, there is a blocked path and a hint that you need the help of someone from a nearby dungeon to open the path.  There is nothing stopping you from going to the dungeon before finding the blocked path, which results in your characters asking for help unblocking the path prior to actually learning about the path.  This does not break the game's plot, but it is a bit of poor forsight.

All in all, this game is a lot better than the original Evoland (which was also a pretty good game).
